p: Probably two of the most economically and ecologically problematic invasive plants in Central Europe are Reynoutria japonica Houtt. (Polygonaceae) and Solidago sp. (Asteraceae). Reynoutria japonica is well known for its high strength of shoot growth sprouting from rhizomes in the spring. Rhizomes can grow up to 2 m in depth, and shoots outgrow areas paved with cobbles and even covered with asphalt. Due to difficult and costly procedures in removing the rhizomes, e.g., in the UK a land for sale on which the knotweed occurs, is much cheaper than the land without these plants [ 9].
